thread.title: Workers, businesses to join 'Day Without Immigrants' boycott on Thursday

author: Nick Williams
title: Workers, businesses to join 'Day Without Immigrants' boycott on Thursday

organizations.name: cst industries & tags nick williams staff

text: Workers, businesses to join 'Day Without Immigrants' boycott on Thursday Feb 15, 2017, 2:57pm CST Updated Feb 15, 2017, 3:49pm CST Industries & Tags Nick Williams Staff reporter Minneapolis / St. Paul Business Journal Share Nick Williams Staff reporter Minneapolis / St. Paul Business Journal Related Content At least two Mexican restaurants in the Twin Cities plan to participate in the boycott,… more filo Dozens of Twin Cities businesses will close and some immigrants may refuse to go to work Thursday in recognition of 'A Day Without Immigrants,' a national boycott aimed to support immigrants living in the U.S. The boycott, which is protesting President Donald Trumps immigration agenda , is asking immigrants not to shop, eat at restaurants, buy gas, or even send their children to school. At least two Mexican restaurants in the Twin Cities plan to participate in the boycott,… more filo At least two dozen businesses in the Twin Cities have said they will participate in the boycott, many of them restaurants such as Milkjam Creamery and World Street Kitchen in Lyndale Avenue, according to the Lake Street Council. St. Paul's El Burrito Mercado, posted on its Facebook page it will close Thursday in honor of its founders, who were immigrants. In Minneapolis, El Nuevo Rodeo also said it will close Thursday to observe the protest. El Nuevo Rodeo is among 23 confirmed businesses along the Lake Street corridor in Minneapolis that will close its doors tomorrow. Other businesses involved include Los Gallos, an express money transfer service, which will close all 15 locations in the Twin Cities; a beauty salon, a pub and an insurance agency, the Lake Street Council said. Hospitality Minnesota alerted its 2,000 members, which consist of restaurants and hotels, about the boycott. In an email sent to the members, Hospitality Minnesota suggested owners talk to their employees about the boycott and "decide on a plan," said Dan McElroy , president and CEO of Hospitality Minnesota. "Restaurants have always been immigrant-friendly employers," McElroy said. Several businesses and workers across the country have taken to social media using the hashtag "#DayWithoutImmigrants" to announce their support of the boycott. The following is a list of businesses along Lake Street that will close Thursday: Las Mojarras
